article_title: Burwell spotlights health insurance enrollment at San Antonio H-E-B
article_text:
Burwell spotlights health insurance enrollment at San Antonio H-E-B

Photo: BOB OWEN /San Antonio Express-News U.S. Department of Health and Human Services Secretary Sylvia...

The nation’s top health services official stood in the middle of the produce section at an H-E-B grocery store on San Antonio’s East Side Monday to talk about affordability and access.

article_metadata.description: She wanted to remind consumers of today’s  enrollment deadline for those wanting their health insurance policies to become active Jan. 1.  Some Texans have been upset by the severe reduction or complete elimination of PPO health insurance plans from the federal exchange in some Texas markets.  PPOs — preferred provider organization plans — have historically been the most popular type of health coverage in Texas because they allow some benefits when patients go out of network for their health care.  Burwell said private insurance companies have seen a “reduction in demand” for PPO health plans.  Burwell noted the number of health insurance companies selling policies to Texas consumers through the exchange has increased for two years in a row.  “We just mentioned to her that we know that the insurance companies are struggling with the pricing, which is affecting the customers, because their rates are going up,” said Adriana Freeman, an independent agent with Insure Prosperity’s San Antonio office.
article_metadata.author.name: By Peggy O'Hare, Staff Writer
